ticket.title: DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder
ticket.original-body:
Currently, if you have and index action that responds to three different types, html, rss, and atom, and you want the rss and atom versions to use one SQL query and the html to use version another, you might do this:
@@@ ruby def index respond_to do |format| format.html { @articles = Article.find(:all, :limit => 10) format.atom { find_all_articles } format.rss { find_all_articles } end end
private
def find_all_articles @articles = Article.find(:all) end @@@
The patch which is attached to this ticket allows you to do this instead:
@@@ ruby def index respond_to do |format| format.html { @articles = Article.find(:all, :limit => 10) } format.atom_and_rss { @articles = Article.find(:all) } end end @@@
In my oppinion this is more readable, and it's DRY and elegant. What do you think? Any ideas to improve this patch is welcomed with open arms. :)
ticket.latest-body:
Currently, if you have and index action that responds to three different types, html, rss, and atom, and you want the rss and atom versions to use one SQL query and the html to use version another, you might do this:
@@@ ruby def index respond_to do |format| format.html { @articles = Article.find(:all, :limit => 10) format.atom { find_all_articles } format.rss { find_all_articles } end end
private
def find_all_articles @articles = Article.find(:all) end @@@
The patch which is attached to this ticket allows you to do this instead:
@@@ ruby def index respond_to do |format| format.html { @articles = Article.find(:all, :limit => 10) } format.atom_and_rss { @articles = Article.find(:all) } end end @@@
In my oppinion this is more readable, and it's DRY and elegant. What do you think? Any ideas to improve this patch is welcomed with open arms. :)
ticket.original-body-html:
Currently, if you have and index action that responds to three different types, html, rss, and atom, and you want the rss and atom versions to use one SQL query and the html to use version another, you might do this:


def index
  respond_to do |format|
    format.html { @articles = Article.find(:all, :limit => 10)
    format.atom { find_all_articles }
    format.rss  { find_all_articles }
  end
end

private

def find_all_articles
  @articles = Article.find(:all)
end

The patch which is attached to this ticket allows you to do this instead:


def index
  respond_to do |format|
    format.html { @articles = Article.find(:all, :limit => 10) }
    format.atom_and_rss { @articles = Article.find(:all) }
  end
end

In my oppinion this is more readable, and it's DRY and elegant. What do you think? Any ideas to improve this patch is welcomed with open arms. :)

version.body:
Currently, if you have and index action that responds to three different types, html, rss, and atom, and you want the rss and atom versions to use one SQL query and the html to use version another, you might do this:
@@@ ruby def index respond_to do |format| format.html { @articles = Article.paginate(:page => params[:page]) } format.atom { find_all_articles } format.rss { find_all_articles } end end
private
def find_all_articles @articles = Article.find(:all) end @@@
The patch which is attached to this ticket allows you to do this instead:
@@@ ruby def index respond_to do |format| format.html { @articles = Article.paginate(:page => params[:page]) } format.atom_and_rss { @articles = Article.find(:all) } end end @@@
In my oppinion this is more readable, and it's DRY and elegant. What do you think? Any ideas to improve this patch is welcomed with open arms. :)
version.body-html:
Currently, if you have and index action that responds to three different types, html, rss, and atom, and you want the rss and atom versions to use one SQL query and the html to use version another, you might do this:


def index
  respond_to do |format|
    format.html { @articles = Article.paginate(:page => params[:page]) }
    format.atom { find_all_articles }
    format.rss  { find_all_articles }
  end
end

private

def find_all_articles
  @articles = Article.find(:all)
end

The patch which is attached to this ticket allows you to do this instead:


def index
  respond_to do |format|
    format.html { @articles = Article.paginate(:page => params[:page]) }
    format.atom_and_rss { @articles = Article.find(:all) }
  end
end

In my oppinion this is more readable, and it's DRY and elegant. What do you think? Any ideas to improve this patch is welcomed with open arms. :)
version.title: DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder

version.body: Are you not supposed to return same data in every other format?
version.body-html: Are you not supposed to return same data in every other format?
version.title: DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder

version.body: @blj: As a groundrule, yes, but you wouldn't paginate an RSS/Atom feed, would you? For example.
version.body-html: @blj: As a groundrule, yes, but you wouldn't paginate an RSS/Atom feed, would you? For example.
version.title: DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder
DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder

version.body:
Forgive me if I'm being naive, but can't you use format.any here?
@@@ ruby def index respond_to do |format| format.html { @articles = Article.paginate(:page => params[:page]) } format.any(:atom, :rss) { @articles = Article.find(:all) } end end @@@
version.body-html:
Forgive me if I'm being naive, but can't you use format.any here?


def index
  respond_to do |format|
    format.html { @articles = Article.paginate(:page => params[:page]) }
    format.any(:atom, :rss) { @articles = Article.find(:all) }
  end
end
version.title: DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder

version.body: @Jeffrey Hardy: Yes, you can, and I must admit, I wasn't aware of that. But anyway I don't think it invalidates the patch. After all, the patch allows a more elegant syntax, and we can still use the any method as a catch-all type.
version.body-html: @Jeffrey Hardy: Yes, you can, and I must admit, I wasn't aware of that. But anyway I don't think it invalidates the patch. After all, the patch allows a more elegant syntax, and we can still use the any method as a catch-all type.
version.title: DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder

version.body: I would like to get this out of the way. First of all: Has anyone got any comments/questions/suggestions for improvements? If not, could this patch either be applied to core or marked as "wontfix"? Having this hanging around on Lighthouse serves no purpose.
version.body-html: I would like to get this out of the way. First of all: Has anyone got any comments/questions/suggestions for improvements? If not, could this patch either be applied to core or marked as "wontfix"? Having this hanging around on Lighthouse serves no purpose.
version.title: DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder

version.body: Jose : Could u please close if we don't need this anymore ?
version.body-html: Jose : Could u please close if we don't need this anymore ?
version.title: DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder

version.body: I agree with Jeffrey, any is the official API for several formats. :)
version.body-html: I agree with Jeffrey, any is the official API for several formats. :)
version.title: DRYing up respond_to: Allow multiple types in same responder
